G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as the action arises under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and the premises are located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as the action arises under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and the premises are located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, §14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violates G.L. c. 239, §8A, which allows tenants to assert defenses and counterclaims when a landlord fails to maintain habitable premises.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7\u00a7410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant also failed to comply with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §§410.000 et seq., which requires landlords to maintain watertight roofs, ceilings, and walls.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences that impair the character or value of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines “quiet enjoyment” in terms that match the proposition, describing it as the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences that impair the character or value of the leased premises. The court links the statutory quiet enjoyment provision back to this common-law meaning and its prior cases, using nearly identical language to the claimed proposition, so the case is solid authority for that statement of the covenant’s scope.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]).”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences that impair the character or value of the leased premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting a tenant’s freedom from serious interference that impairs the character and value of the leasehold. The court then applies that standard to conclude that if tenants cannot use common areas due to drug activity, that would be a serious interference substantially impairing the character of the leased premises. This language aligns directly with the claimed proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. ... In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises."

Gabay v. O\u2019Brien, 57 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Gabay v. O’Brien, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 561 (2003)
Gabay v. O\u2019Brien, 57 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s repeated failure to repair the leaking ceiling constitutes an act of constructive eviction and interference with the quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Gabay v. O\u2019Brien, 57 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion in Gabay v. O’Brien is a criminal rape case focused on the admissibility and use of DNA paternity evidence and related jury instructions. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, constructive eviction, or interference with quiet enjoyment, nor does it address any facts involving a leaking ceiling or failure to make repairs. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a landlord’s repeated failure to repair a leaking ceiling constitutes constructive eviction or interference with quiet enjoyment.
Gabay v. O\u2019Brien, 57 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A Superior Court jury convicted the defendant of raping his twenty-one year old, mentally retarded and autistic sister. On his appeal from his conviction of rape, the defendant contends that the trial judge erred (1) in admitting expert evidence, derived from the results of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) paternity tests… We affirm the conviction.”

Coveney v. Coughlin, 382 Mass. 409 (1981.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy substantial leaks and environmental hazards after notice constitutes an interference within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14.
Coveney v. Coughlin, 382 Mass. 409 (1981.support_reasoning: The opinion in Coveney v. Coughlin does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it address landlord liability for failure to repair leaks or environmental hazards. Instead, it concerns the validity of an emergency eviction procedure in the Boston Housing Authority receivership and tenants’ procedural rights under G.L. c. 121B, §32. There is no discussion that a landlord’s failure to remedy substantial leaks or hazards after notice constitutes an interference within the meaning of c. 186, §14, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
Coveney v. Coughlin, 382 Mass. 409 (1981.relevant_excerpt: We consider then, in this context, the attempted abrogation by the emergency eviction procedure of a tenant’s statutory right to request a hearing by the BHA at least fifteen days prior to any termination of his tenancy (except for nonpayment of rent). G. L. c. 121B, § 32. We do not accept the BHA’s argument that the receivership itself immunizes the court and the receiver from compliance with statutes and regulations that bear on the operations of the BHA. See Perez II, supra at 727-728 (The “BHA in carrying on its housing functions is submissible to and must abide by the ordinary substantive law of the Commonwealth . . .”).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy substantial leaks and environmental hazards after notice constitutes an interference within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case involves noise from a neighboring lounge and constructive eviction/violation of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, not leaks or environmental hazards, and it does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, §14. The court’s reasoning is about when a landlord’s conduct or failure to control another tenant’s activity constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under common law and constructive eviction principles. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific statutory proposition that failure to remedy leaks and environmental hazards after notice constitutes an interference within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that persistent leaks, mold, or other water-related defects materially interfere with a tenant’s beneficial use.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case concerns lack of heat as a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and G.L. c. 186, § 14, not leaks, mold, or other water-related defects. While it does state that failure to provide heat seriously impairs the character and value of the premises and thus breaches quiet enjoyment, it does not address water-related conditions or their impact on beneficial use. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about leaks, mold, or water defects.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: A landlord’s neglect of maintenance and repair duties that results in substantial water penetration and mold contamination constitutes a per se violation of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hemingway (a concurrence/dissent) discusses implied obligations tied to statutory habitability standards and the interdependence of rent and repair duties, but it does not hold that substantial water penetration and mold are a per se breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Indeed, the opinion is focused on habitability and rent abatement, not on declaring specific conditions as automatic violations of quiet enjoyment. The case therefore cannot be cited as authority for a categorical, per se rule that such neglect constitutes a violation of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally, (b) that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations, and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him."

Al\u2010Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.proposition: A landlord’s neglect of maintenance and repair duties that results in substantial water penetration and mold contamination constitutes a per se violation of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2010Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether a statutory lead paint violation is automatically a violation of the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment statute, not about water penetration or mold. The court expressly rejects a per se rule and holds that at least negligent conduct with notice/foreseeability is required for a § 14 quiet enjoyment violation. Thus, it contradicts the claimed proposition that such conditions are per se violations of quiet enjoyment, rather than supporting it.
Al\u2010Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”
